Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Version history table rendering update for accessibility" (#8287) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8196

Previously, version history table always had 2 hardly visible columns: 1 for signature information and another for deprecation information. When user is not authenticated on the web site, we never show the package signature information, so the cells although exist are always empty. The deprecation information is present, but most of the time packages are not deprecated and empty cells do not have any narrator markup, so are not read (but headers are).

This change moves the `Model.IsCertificatesUIEnabled` check up to the lines that generate column header, causing the certificate column to be completely absent for unauthenticated users. Same is done for `Model.IsPackageDeprecationEnabled` but it is always `true` in our case. Also `aria-label` properties added for empty cells when those are rendered.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][Contrast]Color contrast for 'Cancel' button foreground with background is 1.099:1 which is less than 3:1" (#8192) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1188116
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ‚Äã

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450) 


## Note:
Same issue is observed for throughout the application on 'Cancel" button
## Repro Steps:

    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till "Open Profile drop down" and press enter
    Tab till "API Keys" and Press enter
    Tab till "Create button" and press enter
    Tab till "Cancel button" under the 'Select packages'  
    Check whether color contrast for 'Cancel' button's foreground with page background is meeting the required 3:1 ratio or not 

## Actual Results:

Color contrast for 'Cancel' button foreground with background is 1.099:1 which is less than 3:1
## Expected Results:
Low vision user  should be able to identify the button, so it should meet the required color contrast ratio 3:1
## User Impact:
Low vision users may not be able to identify the button if it is not meeting the required color contrast ratio.

## Notes
Looks like this will need a global fix. I believe we use a single set of CSS for the cancel button, so it should be sufficient to change this one time.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y][WCAG2.1][Contrast]The color contrast ratio for the stars under "Stars" column is < 3:1" (#8286) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1069750

# Environment Details:
#URL:https://www.nuget.org/‚Äã
 ‚Äã
## OS Details:‚Äã
Windows 10 Version 1909 Build 18363.657‚Äã
‚Äã
## Browser and Version:‚Äã
Chromium Edge Version 80.0.361.51‚Äã
‚Äã
# Repro Steps:‚Äã
1.Hit the URL "https://www.nuget.org" 
2.Tab till "Packages" link in the top navigation and press enter‚Äã
3.Tab till any existing package and press enter‚Äã
4.Tab till "GitHub Usage" section and press enter‚Äã
5.Using color contrast analyzer, verify the color contrast ratio for the stars under "Stars" column header
‚Äã
## Actual Result:‚Äã
The color contrast ratio for the stars under "Stars" column is 2.51:1 which is < 3:1

‚Äã
## User Impact:‚Äã
Users with visual impairments will find it difficult to access the content
‚Äã
# Notes:
Depending on how these stars are rendered, this will either be very simple, or very not simple.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y][WCAG2.1][Reflow]Dropdown information is cut off when zoomed in." (#8285) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1188115

# Environment Details:
#URL:Application URL for NuGet Service
Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

# OS Details
Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ‚Äã

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450) 



# Note: 
Under 'Members' Administrator dropdown is not visible clearly after applying reflow
# Repro Steps:
Change the Display resolution to 1280*1024 in System display settings
Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
Tab till "Open Profile drop down" and press enter
Tab till "Manage organizations" and Press enter
Tab till "Edit " present in any record the table and press enter
Tab till Certificates and expand it 
Apply reflow and Check whether data is missing or not  
### Actual Results:

Some of the data is missing when reflow is applied under the Certificates
### Expected Results:
User should be able to view the data without missing and all the information should be visible clearly with one scrollbar after applying reflow
### User Impact:
Users will not be able to see the information if it gets overlapped in reflow

# Notes:
We will probably want to update the layout to move the dropdown to the next line when the horizontal width is below a certain amount.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y][WCAG2.1][ARIA]Some status/alert messages are not being read out." (#8284) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Concerning the following:
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1061326
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1061322
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1069948

Fixes  need to be made for the following pages/scenarios:
1. Copy for install instructions on package details page
Steps to Reproduce :
    1. Launch application using provided URL.(https://www.nuget.org/)
    2. Navigated to Home page
    3. Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù)
    4. Look at the package search results and select any package.
    5. Navigate till "Package Manager" and select it.
    6. Start Narrator and navigate till "Copy" control.
    7. Hit enter on the "Copy" control and observe the announcement by screen reader.
2. API Key Generation success message
Steps to Reproduce :
    1. Launch application using provided URL.(https://www.nuget.org/)
    2. Navigated to Home page
    3. Click on ‚ÄúSign in‚Äù option (top right) and click on ‚ÄúSign in with Microsoft‚Äù button
    4. Sign in using MSA on the common Microsoft sign-in page
    5. Go to ‚ÄúAPI Keys‚Äù from the context menu (top left menu dropdown).
    6. Navigate till "Create Control" and expand it.
    7. Fill all the data in the editing fields.
    8. Start Narrator, click on the "Create" button and observe the announcement by screen reader.
3. Deprecation dialog status messages
Repro Steps:‚Äã Note Same issue was observed on "GitHub Usage" page
    1. Start Screen Reader. Hit the URL "https://www.nuget.org" and sign in with valid credentials‚Äã
    2. Tab till "Sign In" link in the top navigation and press enter‚Äã
    3. Tab till "Sign in with Microsoft" button and press enter‚Äã
    4. Select valid user id and press enter‚Äã
    5. Enter any Username, tab till "Register" button and press enter‚Äã
    6. Tab till the user menu button and press enter to expand it. Select "Manage Packages" and press enter‚Äã
    7. Tab till "Published Packages", expand it and select any existing package.(If no packages are available, add a new package)‚Äã
    8. Tab till "Manage Package" link under "Info" and press enter‚Äã
    9. Tab till "Deprecation" section and press enter to expand it‚Äã
    10. Tab till "Select reason(s)" and uncheck all the check boxes. A status message will be displayed on the screen
    11. Check if the screen reader is reading the status message‚Äã

Notes:
All of these are likely missing aria-live regions describing them. Including an aria-live and role to the respective elements that need to be read out should be sufficient. See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8238 for an example of a fix.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Provide a mechanism to validate packages against nuget.org prior to upload" (#8283) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

The validations performed by NuGet client at pack time are different than those that are performed by nuget.org at upload time. This is unavoidable for some long running validations (consider virus scanning or package repository signing) or validations that require online data (consider namespace reservation or API key scopes).

Many teams, both internal and external, have run into problems where they are trying to release packages on an important Release Day but are blocked because nuget.org validations fail at the last minute.

This last minute failure is hugely painful because:

1. It may require the team to recreate the packages with a small tweak (perhaps a metadata fix-up)
1. It may require a whole _wave_ of packages to be republished. Consider A depends on B depends on C and B fails validation.
    - This gets even more complicated if A is already published and nuget.org does not allow deletion... but A must be republished!
1. It may delay a Release Date due to this extra scramble. This can be really bad if the release is security critical or already communicated to other partners/customers in branding/blog/etc.

### Describe the solution you'd like

There should be a way to validate packages in advanced. One more complicated solution would be a staging feature described by https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/3931, but other cheaper solutions exists:

For example:
1. Provide a magic push endpoint that performs all synchronous validation
    - Pros: could perform API key, ID prefix, metadata etc validation
    - Cons: misses author signing validation and virus scanning which must be done asynchronously
1. Provide an offline tool that performs all of the same validations as the push endpoint
    - Pros: relative cheap to implement
    - Cons: does not account for online data like ID prefix reservation, can drift over time (e.g. new validation online, old tool)

I propose that we should consider a solution cheaper than staging that allows a package owner to push a package in a "validation" mode such that all of the synchronous validations are done but the package is not committed. This seems like a reasonable balance between implementation cost and validation coverage. We could consider a ticket-based approach in the future where asynchronous validations are completed as well but the package is still not committed. Imagine pushing to this validation endpoint and receiving a GUID which can be used to check the status of the asynchronous validation step at a later time (client responsibility to poll).

### Additional context

The [NuGet.VerifyMicrosoftPackage](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/tree/master/src/VerifyMicrosoftPackage) tool was implemented to address part of these concerns, specifically for Microsoft-specific metadata validations.

Some teams have taken the approach of pushing their packages to https://int.nugettest.org/ ("INT" environment) in advance. This is a decent workaround but has some drawbacks.
- Pros: provides online validation that can closely mimic nuget.org, such as virus scanning
- Cons: data on INT is independent from PROD meaning namespace reservation or author signature validation might succeed on INT but fail on PROD. Also, INT could have a newer version of code than PROD since it is our pro-PROD validation environment.

### Examples of "surprise" validation failures

- License file encoding: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7733
- Case sensitivity of license file path: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9817
- Specific SPDX identifier requirements: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8280

... and many more.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][WCAG2.1]Some of the contents of API Key page get overlapped when screen is zoom to 400%." (#8281) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1061307
‚Äã
Environment Details:
Application Name: NuGet Service
Application URL:https://www.nuget.org/
Windows Version - Windows10 
Edge Version-Microsoft Edge 44.18362.449.0
Chrome Version- Version 79.0.3945.130 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Pre-requisite:
Set the desktop size value to 1280 x 1024.

Note:
Same issue is observed in Upload packages page

Steps to Reproduce :
1.Launch application using provided URL.(https://www.nuget.org/)
2.Navigated to Home page
3.Click on ‚ÄúSign in‚Äù option (top right) and click on ‚ÄúSign in with Microsoft‚Äù button
4.Sign in using MSA on the common Microsoft sign-in page
5.Go to ‚ÄúAPI Keys‚Äù from the context menu (top left menu dropdown).
6.Navigate till "Create Control" and expand it.
7.Observe that some of the contents get overlapped when the screen is zoom to 400%.

Actual: 
When the screen is zoomed to 400%,  Some of the contents present on the screen get overlapped.
The below data shown in the screenshot gets overlapped after zooming the screen :
Image

Expected: 
When screen is zoomed to 400%, all the contents present on the screen should not get overlapped and should appear properly on the screen.

User Impact: 
Low vision users will find difficulty in viewing and reading the content present on the screen when zoomed to 400%.

Notes:
See this screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11051729/96502433-a0188f80-1206-11eb-89ea-6097e412051e.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Cookies] Expire and set the domain of Google Analytics cookies" (#8263) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
- Expire Google Analytics cookies in a year;
- Set the domain as 'none', to avoid sharing Google Analytics cookies with the status page.
References:
https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/analyticsjs/cookies-user-id
https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/analyticsjs/field-reference#cookieDomain
https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/analyticsjs/field-reference#cookieExpires

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[CPVM] Disable pinning of the central transitive dependencies " (#10132) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Per request  from internal and external customers, disable the enforcing/pinning of package versions for transitive dependencies defined in the CentralManagement file.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NU5129 is not so clever to detect a file renamed by the nuspec" (#10162) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This warning confused me because it is straight up gaslighting me.

`WARNING: NU5129: - At least one .props file was found in 'build/native/include/', but 'build/native/BCGControlBarPro-Win32.props' was not.`

Except, it was:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36889813/96605612-51debb80-12ee-11eb-9897-26d32c745cc2.png)

```xml
    <file src="build\BCGControlBarPro.props" target="build\BCGControlBarPro-Win32.props"/>
    <file src="build\BCGControlBarPro.targets" target="build\BCGControlBarPro-Win32.targets"/>
```
Could you please either get nuget.exe to acknowledge my nuspec has renamed the file appropriately, or make `build\BCGControlBarPro-Win32.props` a folder, not a file, so that the warning is accurate?

[The docs say I'm doing the right thing](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/errors-and-warnings/nu5129#solution)

Ta.

---
#### Document Details

‚ö† *Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ‚ûü GitHub issue linking.*

* ID: 81f342a2-c4fa-9704-bf6d-c739d974eb6e
* Version Independent ID: f5f90f1e-9d35-c109-aff3-2f657eaa0c57
* Content: [NuGet Warning NU5129](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/errors-and-warnings/nu5129)
* Content Source: [docs/reference/errors-and-warnings/NU5129.md](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/blob/master/docs/reference/errors-and-warnings/NU5129.md)
* Product: **nuget**
* GitHub Login: @zivkan
* Microsoft Alias: **karann**

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Using NuGet offline | Disable certificate check" (#10161) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm using NuGet on a Windows maschine without internet connection and a local repository manager (Nexus).
The problem is that NuGet tries to verify the certificates even if the repository is trusted.

For example I want to download Newtensoft.Json from my repository server.
The download is fast but after the download NuGet tries to verify the certificat / signing and contacts digicert.com in this case resulting in a timeout.
The hole proccess to download and trying to verify the package takes nearly 3 minutes which is way too much.

Is there a way to disable certificate checking completly and speed up the proccess?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Avoid cache with local sources" (#10160) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

We have nuget packages from 2 sources: nuget.org and local machine. I have noticed that the command "nuget restore '*.sln' Nocache" continues getting packages from my local source, is it a bug?Its like the parameter "NoCache" doesnt apply for local sources.

I have to run before "nuget locals all -clear" to make it work.

I am running Nuget 5.7.0.

Many thanks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Generating MSBuild Binary log from nuget restore command" (#10135) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
How can I generate MSBuild Binary log from nuget client commands like restore ? 

`nuget restore` resolves into something like `msbuild.exe "%temp%\NuGetScratch\ro0d0kct.z0t.nugetinputs.targets" /t:GenerateRestoreGraphFile /nologo /nr:false /v:q /p:NuGetRestoreTargets="%temp%\NuGetScratch\w3s4ivaf.f43.nugetrestore.targets" /p:RestoreUseCustomAfterTargets="True" /p:RestoreTaskAssemblyFile="<path to nuget.exe>" /p:RestoreSolutionDirectory="<path to sln directory>" /p:SolutionDir="<path to solution dir>" /p:SolutionNam=<solution name>`

How can I get it to pass `/bl` to msbuild so that a binary log is output at the end of nuget restore?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CPVM equivalent of GlobalPackageReference?" (#10159) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We're looking at migrating from https://github.com/microsoft/MSBuildSdks/tree/master/src/CentralPackageVersions to the built-in central package versioning feature, and (unless I missed it) I didn't see an equivalent of `GlobalPackageReference`.

I'm guessing that for all of our (many) build/analyzer packages, we can do the equivalent and manually add both `PackageVersion` and `PackageReference` (with IncludeAssets and PrivateAssets set as `GlobalPackageReference` does)? Is there any reason we shouldn't add the `PackageReference`s directly in Directory.Packages.props?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "unit test to compare lock file target libraries in project.assets.json file with Dependencies tree" (#9971) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: This issue has been created to develop a unit test to compare lock file target libraries in `project.assets.json` file with Dependencies tree. Inspired by [this](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3598#discussion_r475776278) code review comment.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Use LazyIntializer API to initialize a target type in a multi threaded environment" (#8738) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
In the current [implementation](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/c1f6915918b82c096bbd666bd9c18528f1f70630/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio/IDE/ExtensibleSourceRepositoryProvider.cs#L54) object is always locked even-though target type is already initialized.  Learnt from this [doc](https://github.com/microsoft/referencesource/blob/17b97365645da62cf8a49444d979f94a59bbb155/mscorlib/system/threading/LazyInitializer.cs#L197) that there is a .NET framework implementation to accomplish the same logic. `This issue is created to track other lazy initializations which rely on a similar pattern`.

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): VS UI

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Pushing multiple packages in CI is causing a file lock, failing 2nd push" (#10158) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
When using CI (GitHub Actions and `dotnet nuget push` with *.nupkg, the files are found and a first package is pushed, but then the second fails.

Example: https://github.com/timheuer/strava-net/runs/1243834288#step:7:19

```
Pushing strava-net.1.0.0.symbols.nupkg to '/home/runner/work/strava-net/strava-net/published/'...
Your package was pushed.
Pushing strava-net.1.0.0.nupkg to '/home/runner/work/strava-net/strava-net/published/'...
error: The process cannot access the file '/home/runner/work/strava-net/strava-net/published/strava-net.1.0.0.nupkg' because it is being used by another process.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Cannot use relative URLs in dotnet push" (#10157) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
I‚Äôm trying to use `dotnet nuget push` with *.nupkg and 1) the docs are wrong (I submitted a bug) 2) the source parameter seems to require a fully-qualified source and cannot use relative roots?
 
I‚Äôm doing this in CI and am trying to basically use ‚Äú.‚Äù As the source directory but looks like the CLI treats this as too literally and doesn‚Äôt like that.

From conversation it appears it could be 
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/65abcc61f73ab3d87928495f789ec74011edde7f/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/Utility/PackageSourceProviderExtensions.cs#L47
Versus using `RelativeOrAbsolute`
